title: José Mota (footballer, born 1964)
text:
José Albano Ferreira da Mota (born 25 February 1964) is a Portuguese retired <a href="Association%20football">footballer</a> who played mainly as a <a href="Defender%20%28association%20football%29%23Full-back">right back</a>, and is the current <a href="Manager%20%28association%20football%29">manager</a> of <a href="Leix%C3%B5es%20S.C.">Leixões</a>.
He spent most of his playing career with <a href="F.C.%20Pa%C3%A7os%20de%20Ferreira">Paços de Ferreira</a>, where he also began his coaching career and won two <a href="Segunda%20Liga">Segunda Liga</a> titles. In two decades as a manager he led eight teams in <a href="Primeira%20Liga">Primeira Liga</a>, and won the <a href="Ta%C3%A7a%20de%20Portugal">Taça de Portugal</a> for <a href="C.D.%20Aves">Aves</a> in <a href="2018%20Ta%C3%A7a%20de%20Portugal%20Final">2018</a>.
Football career.
Mota was born in <a href="Paredes%2C%20Portugal">Paredes</a>, <a href="Porto%20District">Porto District</a>. After humble beginnings with <a href="Aliados%20Lordelo%20F.C.">Aliados do Lordelo FC</a>, he went on to spend nearly a decade at <a href="F.C.%20Pa%C3%A7os%20de%20Ferreira">F.C. Paços de Ferreira</a>, often leading the club as its <a href="Captain%20%28association%20football%29">captain</a>. After retiring, he immediately joined their coaching staff, being promoted to head manager in 2000. In 2003, he had a short stint with <a href="C.D.%20Santa%20Clara">C.D. Santa Clara</a> in the <a href="Azores">Azores</a>, but returned to Paços shortly after.
In the <a href="2006%E2%80%9307%20Primeira%20Liga">2006–07 season</a>, Mota <a href="2007%E2%80%9308%20UEFA%20Cup">led</a> Paços de Ferreira to the <a href="UEFA%20Europa%20League">UEFA Cup</a> for the first time after a sixth-place finish in the league. The northerners would subsequently lose in the first round of the <a href="UEFA">European competition</a> against <a href="AZ%20Alkmaar">AZ Alkmaar</a>, 0–1 on aggregate.
In July 2008, Mota left Paços and joined <a href="Leix%C3%B5es%20S.C.">Leixões S.C.</a> also in the <a href="Primeira%20Liga">Primeira Liga</a>. On 9 February 2010, with the <a href="Matosinhos">Matosinhos</a> team ranking <a href="2009%E2%80%9310%20Primeira%20Liga">second from bottom</a>, he was sacked.
Mota returned to active in November 2010, being appointed at <a href="C.F.%20Os%20Belenenses">C.F. Os Belenenses</a> who was struggling in the <a href="Segunda%20Liga">second division</a> and eventually <a href="2010%E2%80%9311%20Liga%20de%20Honra">narrowly avoided relegation</a>. Between February 2012 and October of the following year, he coached <a href="Vit%C3%B3ria%20F.C.">Vitória F.C.</a> in the top level.
On 2 September 2014, Mota was hired by <a href="Gil%20Vicente%20F.C.">Gil Vicente F.C.</a> as a replacement to <a href="Jo%C3%A3o%20de%20Deus%20%28footballer%29">João de Deus</a>, fired after three losses in as <a href="2014%E2%80%9315%20Primeira%20Liga">many top division games</a>. On 25 March 2016, after a period of inactivity, he signed with second tier club <a href="C.D.%20Feirense">C.D. Feirense</a>, leading it to <a href="2015%E2%80%9316%20LigaPro">promotion</a> after four years and being relieved of his duties in December of the same year.
Mota was appointed at <a href="C.D.%20Aves">C.D. Aves</a> on 18 February 2017, achievement <a href="2016%E2%80%9317%20LigaPro">another promotion</a> to the <a href="Portuguese%20football%20league%20system">Portuguese top flight</a> but leaving subsequently by mutual consent. The 53-year-old moved abroad for the first time in late June, signing a two-year contract with <a href="CS%20Sfaxien">CS Sfaxien</a> from the <a href="Tunisian%20Ligue%20Professionnelle%201">Tunisian Ligue Professionnelle 1</a> and leading them to <a href="2017%20CAF%20Confederation%20Cup">the quarter-finals</a> of the <a href="CAF%20Confederation%20Cup">CAF Confederation Cup</a>.
Mota returned to both Portugal and Aves on 24 January 2018, replacing the suspended <a href="Lito%20Vidigal">Lito Vidigal</a> as well as being appointed senior football and youth system coordinator. On 18 April, he took the club to its <a href="2017%E2%80%9318%20Ta%C3%A7a%20de%20Portugal">first-ever final</a> of the <a href="Ta%C3%A7a%20de%20Portugal">Taça de Portugal</a> after disposing of lowly <a href="Caldas%20S.C.">Caldas S.C.</a> 3–1 on aggregate, defeating <a href="Sporting%20CP">Sporting CP</a> 2–1 in <a href="2018%20Ta%C3%A7a%20de%20Portugal%20Final">the decisive match</a>.
On 16 January 2019, Mota left Aves by mutual consent after their elimination from the <a href="2018%E2%80%9319%20Ta%C3%A7a%20de%20Portugal">quarter-finals of the cup</a> by <a href="S.C.%20Braga">S.C. Braga</a>. He returned to the league on 10 March at <a href="G.D.%20Chaves">G.D. Chaves</a> on a deal until 2020, and reiterated his commitment to the club after they were relegated on the last day of the season with a 5–2 defeat to <a href="C.D.%20Tondela">C.D. Tondela</a>; he managed his 400th game in Portugal's top flight on 21 April, a 2–2 draw against <a href="Belenenses%20SAD">Belenenses SAD</a>. 
On 19 December 2019, with the team <a href="2019%E2%80%9320%20LigaPro">in eighth</a>, Mota's contract was terminated and he was replaced by <a href="C%C3%A9sar%20Peixoto">César Peixoto</a>. Thirteen months later, he was back at work at 16th-placed Leixões, after over a decade away.
Honours.
Manager.
Paços Ferreira
Aves
